Posts.Title: has any body else had a similiar experience

Posts.Content: Hi chloecat45, I felt compelled to respond to you. whether it will help or not i dont know. I am a 35 year old Osteopath diagnosed in June this year with IDC. As an osteopath my life is about letting the body heal itself by putting it in the best possible place to do so. I worked very hard for 5 years to qualify. I know ALL about research, statistics, conventional medicine and alternatives. I have read sooo many papers now on all treatments available, and all the side effects of each treatment. Your choice is basically choosing between proven,  researched methods or not yet proven alternatives. It is your choice. I will say that in 5 -10 years time the choices will be different, and for example even how they target radiotherapy will probably be different, but believe me they didn't get to where they are now lightly. My grandma died in her 40's, 30 years ago through not having the research we are privileged to have now.  I would have happily chosen alternative methods if i believed that would be enough to keep me alive in 10 years time. I personally decided I was not willing to take that chance. The alternatives then become complementary instead of alternative. The research is there for a reason. As it happens the "slice and burn" has not been too bad. In fact for me it was "slice and slice and burn" but i have changed my diet completely, taken up yoga and meditation everyday, got rid of all people in my life who drain me and with a few minor glitch days along the way I have sailed through. So i know conventional seems horrid but really its not the NHS fobbing you off. No-one can make the decision for you. Ali x
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hello everyone, This is going to seem really ridiculous but instead of stressing about the treatment I am now on one about my christmas holiday!!! I am a skier and we go every year and i've always wanted to go to Canada or USA to ski there as its supposed to be amazing. So being diagnosed this year and coming up to the end of treatment (except for tamoxifen) I decided i would reward myself with the best xmas trip ever in whistler. NOW however being the loser that I am!! I think instead of rewarding and celebrating I am now tempting fate. If I go on this holiday am I ticking it off before worse things happen and the BC comes back to get me!?!? do you undertsnad what i mean??? I know its ridiculous. Just as I write this I know its ridiculous but what if i do??? Ali x
